description.narrative: The World Citizens Panel is an impact measurement method developed by Oxfam. The focus is on measuring changes in peoples' lives bycombining quantitative research (impact surveys) among Oxfam#s target population and a control group with qualitative research (stories of change) and thus give participants a voice. This project will help Oxfam understand how programmes can be improved, as well as contribute to the public debate on effectiveness of development cooperation. The project builds on a previous startup workshopin which Oxfam agreed on how to undertake this impact survey. Thereafter a reflection workshop was held to discuss the main findings based on the data collected among 14 partners with more than 4.000 respondents. The next step is to train partners in collectingqualitative stories of change in order to deepen the insights gained from the impact survey and get a better understanding of the changes that happened in people's lives. An impact report will be published, based on the surveysand the stories of change. For more information on the background of the World Citizens Panel, preliminary results and publications, please visit www.worldcitizenspanel.com

participating-org.narrative: The Uganda Land Alliance (ULA) was formed in May 1995 as a consortium of local and international non-governmental organisations andindividuals lobbying and advocating for fair land laws and policies to address the land rights of the poor men and women, disadvantaged and vulnerable groups and individuals in Uganda. The Alliance has for the last three years been engaged in five major activities. These are; Lobby and advocacy of policy makers, public awareness, Land Rights Protection, Research and Documentation, monitoring the Implementation of the Land Act 1998 and networking and sharing information. The membership of ULA currently stands at forty three organisations, both local and international, and ten individuals. The mission is to enhance access, control and ownership of land by the poor women, men, children and other marginalised groups through the promotion of fair policies and laws for the protection ofland rights. For the period 2002 to 2005, Uganda Land Alliance identified four strategic objectives with specific prioritised focusareas. The strategic objectives are; - Increased awareness of the poor women, men, children and other marginalised groups of their land rights and obligations. - Have fair laws and policies that protect the land rights of the poor women, men and children, and other marginalised groups; - Effective participation of Alliance members and enhanced collaboration with other organisations and institutions and, - Efficient and effective management of the programs The Alliance works mainly on land rights issues. Approaches: - Research and documentation on land law and policy; - Land rights protection for marginalised group; - Lobby and advocacy for land law reform; - National land policy development. The above approaches are based on the following strategies: - Action Research to feed intothe lobby and advocacy process - Awareness raising through Media - Formation and management of Land Rights Centres at District level which provide information to the public and give legal advice. - Sensitisation of both men and women at local community level. - Partnering with Member Organisations to increase the capacities. Achievements: The external review of the Alliances program 1998-2001revealed the following achievements: - The alliances conducted workshops on community awareness on the Land Act in over 10 districtswhere over 10,000 men and women were reached. In 1999/2000 over 3000 people at grassroots level were reached out of which 30% were women. These were highly successful especially in Kibaale and Kapchworwa districts where land rights centres were based. The Alliance received several requests for workshops to be carried out to resolve immediate land problems. The Alliance also held workshops togive legal advice to the communities. And the communities used this information to fight for their rights in courts of law. - The alliance was instrumental in lobbying for the recognition of customary land tenure, communal holdings, and the representation of women in administration structures and introduction of the Land Fund for tenants on registered land. The Land Act contains some of the provisions reflecting the position proposed and promoted by the Alliance. - The alliance is credited with the introduction of the debate on womens rights to land and lobbying for the legislation of co-ownership of land by spouses, an issue that caused intense public debate. - The alliances advocacy efforts have gained recognition and respect from national level policy makersand the alliance hasparticipated on a number of committees and working groups in the Ministry of Water, Land and Environment. - The alliance sits on the working group for the national land policy, the focus group on sensitisation of the land act, the Forest Sector Plan Working groupon gender and poverty and many other. - The alliance has managed to open land rights centres in Kampala, Kibaale and Kapchorwa thathave been instrumental in providing information and resolving disputes. - The Alliance hasachieved collaboration and linkages with other actors and development partners in the land sector.
